affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: We are currently estimating that we will have processed the backlog for OS X builds on open source repositories in approximately 8 hours. Take note, however, that it might be faster than that since there are fewer builds at this time. We will continue to keep you informed about the situation and update the ETA accordingly.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: We have caught up with the backlog for OS X builds on private repositories. We are continuing to process the backlog of OS X builds for open source repositories. Although this backlog is again higher than we last reported, it seems to have peaked and we are now seeing a downward trend. Hopefully, we will have an ETA with our next update. Thank you.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

Unfortunately, the backlog for open source builds is a bit higher than when we last provided an update hence it will take longer to process entirely. Thanks for hanging in there.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: We are currently processing OS X builds at full capacity. We estimate that the backlog of build jobs for private repositories should be consumed in about 3 hours (though this might change with the traffic of the PST timezone). The backlog for build jobs for open source repositories will take longer as it's currently increasing. We will continue to monitor things and give you an update again soon. Thank you for your understanding.

incidents.name: Missed private build requests, Tuesday 4 October 2016

incident_updates.body:
Starting at 06:35 UTC on Tuesday, 4 October 2016, we were unable to receive build requests on travis-ci.com for approximately 50 minutes.

That morning, GitHub experienced a service outage. Once the issue at GitHub was rectified, our system was flooded with build requests at a much greater rate than usual. This caused our Redis instances to hit their maximum allocated memory usage. Our system recovered quickly, but sadly, around 4000 build requests were irretrievably dropped.

We are sorry for the difficulties this will have caused. We are already taking steps to avoid this in the future, including splitting our Redis usage across a greater number of dedicated instances and storing GitHub API events redundantly, in order to replay them in the event of an outage.
